qas.question: What was the main requirement for electric feeder stations?

answers.text: line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated

qas.question: What invention prevented lines from getting mixed?
What was the part of wire in Phase Break sections an arc being drawn from one wire to another?
How were the drivers warned to start coasting the train?
What should the driver do in order to open and close the circuit breaker?

answers.text: to shut off power and coast

qas.question: Charged Sections consist of an earthed section of what?

plausible_answers.text: automatically opens and closes the circuit breaker

qas.question: In the US, a system known as Automatic Power Control does what?
Typically what are in use all the time?

plausible_answers.text: an arc being drawn from one live section to the other

qas.question: The earthed section allows for what?
What must not be coasting to prevent the risk of an arc being drawn?

context: To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing, sections of <a0_0>line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated<a0_0/>. This is achieved by <b7_0>Neutral Sections<b7_0/> (also known as <a1_0>Phase Breaks<a1_0/>), usually provided at feeder stations and midway between them although, typically, only half are in use at any time, the others being provided to allow a feeder station to be shut down and power provided from adjacent feeder stations. Neutral Sections usually consist of an earthed section of <b5_0>wire<b5_0/> which is separated from the live wires on either side by insulating material, typically ceramic beads, designed so that the pantograph will smoothly run from one section to the other. <a2_0>The earthed section<a2_0/> prevents <b8_0>an arc being drawn from one live section to the other<b8_0/>, as the voltage difference may be higher than the normal system voltage if the live sections are on different phases and the protective circuit breakers may not be able to safely interrupt the considerable current that would flow. To prevent the risk of an arc being drawn across from one section of wire to earth, when passing through the neutral section, <b9_0>the train<b9_0/> must be coasting and the circuit breakers must be open. In many cases, this is done manually by the drivers. To help them, a <a3_0>warning board<a3_0/> is provided just before both the neutral section and an advance warning some distance before. A further board is then provided after the neutral section to tell drivers to re-close the circuit breaker, although drivers must not do this until the rear pantograph has passed this board. In the UK, a system known as Automatic Power Control (APC) <b6_0>automatically opens and closes the circuit breaker<b6_0/>, this being achieved by using sets of permanent magnets alongside the track communicating with a detector on the train. The only action needed by the driver is <a4_0>to shut off power and coast<a4_0/> and therefore warning boards are still provided at and on the approach to neutral sections.
